title: Do the low-level requirements and software architecture developed conform to the Software Design Standards and are they traceable, verifiable, and consistent?
description: Do the low-level requirements and software architecture developed conform to the Software Design Standards and are they traceable, verifiable, and consistent?

title: If low-level requirements or architecture are expressed as a model, is it consistent and verifiable?
description: If low-level requirements or architecture are expressed as a model, is it consistent and verifiable?

title: If low-level requirements are expressed as a model, do they conform to the Modeling Standards?
description: If low-level requirements are expressed as a model, do they conform to the Modeling Standards?

title: If low-level requirements are expressed as a design model, are they traceable to high-level requirements?
description: If low-level requirements are expressed as a design model, are they traceable to high-level requirements?

title: Have the derived low-level requirements and the reason for their existence been defined?
description: Have the derived low-level requirements and the reason for their existence been defined?

title: Have the derived low-level requirements been analyzed against higher level requirements to ensure they are not compromised?
description: Have the derived low-level requirements been analyzed against higher level requirements to ensure they are not compromised?

title: Have the derived low-level requirements been fed back to the system/safety processes? Note:  Partitioning or architectural SW design aspects may need to be captured as derived requirements and fed to saftey.
description: Have the derived low-level requirements been fed back to the system/safety processes? Note:  Partitioning or architectural SW design aspects may need to be captured as derived requirements and fed to saftey.

title: Have the interfaces between software components (in the form of data and control flow) been defined and analyzed to be consistent between components?
description: Have the interfaces between software components (in the form of data and control flow) been defined and analyzed to be consistent between components?

title: Are control flow and data flow appropriately monitored as per safety-related requirements (e.g., watchdog timers, cross channel comparisons, etc.)?
description: Are control flow and data flow appropriately monitored as per safety-related requirements (e.g., watchdog timers, cross channel comparisons, etc.)?

title: Are failure condition responses consistent with safety-related requirements?
description: Are failure condition responses consistent with safety-related requirements?

title: Have inadequate or incorrect inputs detected during software design been provided to the system, requirements or planning processes as necessary?
description: Have inadequate or incorrect inputs detected during software design been provided to the system, requirements or planning processes as necessary?

title: <html>Are all model elements categorized as either model elements that <u>do</u>, or <u>do not</u> represent low-level requirements (including derived) or software architecture?</html>
description: <html>Are all model elements categorized as either model elements that <u>do</u>, or <u>do not</u> represent low-level requirements (including derived) or software architecture?</html>

title: Has class hierarchy been developed based on high-level requirements?
description: Has class hierarchy been developed based on high-level requirements?

title: Has a locally type-consistent class hierarchy been developed with associated low-level requirements wherever substitution is relied upon?
description: Has a locally type-consistent class hierarchy been developed with associated low-level requirements wherever substitution is relied upon?

title: Has the strategy for memory management been developed as part of the software architecture?
description: Has the strategy for memory management been developed as part of the software architecture?

title: Has the strategy for exception management been developed as part of the software architecture?
description: Has the strategy for exception management been developed as part of the software architecture?

title: For reused components, have the resulting derived requirements and deactivated functions been identified?
description: For reused components, have the resulting derived requirements and deactivated functions been identified?

title: If the design contains user-modifiable software, is the non-modifiable code protected from the modifiable component to prevent interference?
description: If the design contains user-modifiable software, is the non-modifiable code protected from the modifiable component to prevent interference?

title: If the design contains user-modifiable software, has the means provided to change the modifiable component been demonstrated to be the only means by which the component can be changed?
description: If the design contains user-modifiable software, has the means provided to change the modifiable component been demonstrated to be the only means by which the component can be changed?

title: If the design has deactivated code, has a mechanism been designed to ensure deactivated code has no adverse impact on active functions/components?
description: If the design has deactivated code, has a mechanism been designed to ensure deactivated code has no adverse impact on active functions/components?

title: If the design has deactivated code, is there evidence showing deactivated code is disabled for unintended environments?
description: If the design has deactivated code, is there evidence showing deactivated code is disabled for unintended environments?

title: Does the Trace Data demonstrate a bi-directional associations between low-level requirements and high-level requirements?
description: Does the Trace Data demonstrate a bi-directional associations between low-level requirements and high-level requirements?

title: Do the software low-level requirements comply with high-level requirements? (i.e. Do they satisfy the high-level requirements and derived requirements, and is the design basis for their existence correctly defined?)
description: Do the software low-level requirements comply with high-level requirements? (i.e. Do they satisfy the high-level requirements and derived requirements, and is the design basis for their existence correctly defined?)

title: Have the software low-level requirements been independently verified to comply with high-level requirements? (i.e. Do they satisfy the high-level requirements and derived requirements, and is the design basis for their existence correctly defined?)
description: Have the software low-level requirements been independently verified to comply with high-level requirements? (i.e. Do they satisfy the high-level requirements and derived requirements, and is the design basis for their existence correctly defined?)

title: Are the low-level requirements accurate and consistent? (I.e., Is each low level requirement accurate, unambiguous and not conflicting with another?)
description: Are the low-level requirements accurate and consistent? (I.e., Is each low level requirement accurate, unambiguous and not conflicting with another?)

title: Have the low-level requirements been independently verified to be  accurate and consistent? (I.e., Is each low level requirement accurate, unambiguous and not conflicting with another?)
description: Have the low-level requirements been independently verified to be  accurate and consistent? (I.e., Is each low level requirement accurate, unambiguous and not conflicting with another?)

title: Are low-level requirements compatible with the target computer? (I.e., No conflicts exist between the software requirements and hardware/software features of the target computer, especially, the use of resources (such as bus loading), system response times, and input/output hardware.)
description: Are low-level requirements compatible with the target computer? (I.e., No conflicts exist between the software requirements and hardware/software features of the target computer, especially, the use of resources (such as bus loading), system response times, and input/output hardware.)

title: Can each low-level requirements be verified?
description: Can each low-level requirements be verified?

title: Does each low-level requirement conform to standards (with any deviations justified)?
description: Does each low-level requirement conform to standards (with any deviations justified)?

title: Have the accuracy and behavior of the proposed algorithms have been verified, especially in the area of discontinuities?
description: Have the accuracy and behavior of the proposed algorithms have been verified, especially in the area of discontinuities?

title: Have the accuracy and behavior of the proposed algorithms have been verified with independence, especially in the area of discontinuities?
description: Have the accuracy and behavior of the proposed algorithms have been verified with independence, especially in the area of discontinuities?

title: Is the software architecture compatible with high-level requirements?
description: Is the software architecture compatible with high-level requirements?

title: Has the software architecture been independently verified to be compatible with high-level requirements?
description: Has the software architecture been independently verified to be compatible with high-level requirements?

title: Is the software architecture consistent?
description: Is the software architecture consistent?

title: Has the software architecture been independently verified to be consistent?
description: Has the software architecture been independently verified to be consistent?

title: Is the software architecture compatible with the target computer? (I.e., No conflicts exist in the architecture, especially initialization, asynchronous operation, synchronization and interrupts, between the software architecture and the hardware/software features of the target computer.)
description: Is the software architecture compatible with the target computer? (I.e., No conflicts exist in the architecture, especially initialization, asynchronous operation, synchronization and interrupts, between the software architecture and the hardware/software features of the target computer.)

title: Can the software architecture be verified? (e.g., there are no unbounded recursive algorithms)
description: Can the software architecture be verified? (e.g., there are no unbounded recursive algorithms)

title: Does the software architecture conform to the standards and if applicable, have any deviations to the standards been justified?
description: Does the software architecture conform to the standards and if applicable, have any deviations to the standards been justified?

title: Has the Software partitioning integrity been confirmed?
description: Has the Software partitioning integrity been confirmed?

title: Has the Software partitioning integrity been confirmed with independence?
description: Has the Software partitioning integrity been confirmed with independence?

title: Have design-related configuration items been identified?
description: Have design-related configuration items been identified?

title: Have design-related baselines and traceability been established?
description: Have design-related baselines and traceability been established?

title: Has problem reporting been established for design-related items?
description: Has problem reporting been established for design-related items?

title: Has change control been established for design-related items?
description: Has change control been established for design-related items?

title: Has change review been established for design-related items?
description: Has change review been established for design-related items?

title: Has configuration status accounting been established for design-related items?
description: Has configuration status accounting been established for design-related items?

title: Have the planned transition criteria for entering the Software Coding Process as identified in the Software Development Plan been satisfied?
description: Have the planned transition criteria for entering the Software Coding Process as identified in the Software Development Plan been satisfied?
